description: The Holy Mother Virgin Nativity Cathedral, also known as the Cathedral of the Mother of God, stands as the principal cathedral of the Diocese of Batumi and Lazeti in Georgia's coastal city of Batumi. Originally constructed between 1898 and 1903 as a Roman Catholic church, this magnificent neo-Gothic structure was commissioned by the wealthy Zubalashvili brothers, prominent Georgian Catholic businessmen and philanthropists, in response to their mother's wish for a memorial to her soul. Designed by Polish architect Aleksander Rogojski, the cathedral represents a rare and stunning example of Gothic Revival architecture on Georgia's Black Sea coast. The building features a distinctive white stone facade adorned with decorative red stone elements, three domes (highly unusual for Gothic architecture), twin spires, ornate carvings, and pointed arches. During the Soviet era, the cathedral experienced a dramatic transformation when it was closed to worshippers and repurposed as a high-voltage laboratory, a stark departure from its sacred purpose. In 1989, amid the period of Perestroika and religious revival, the structure was transferred to the Georgian Orthodox Church and consecrated by Catholicos-Patriarch Elijah II on May 16, 1989. Today, the cathedral serves as a functioning place of worship and a beloved landmark in Batumi's historic center, showcasing vibrant Orthodox frescoes, an ornate iconostasis with gilded icons, and spectacular stained glass windows that flood the sanctuary with kaleidoscopic light.
highlights: The cathedral's large stained glass windows are its most unique characteristic, competing in beauty with the finest examples of French Gothic architecture and casting colorful, kaleidoscopic light throughout the sanctuary that creates a mesmerizing visual experience.

Three distinctive domes crown the structure, an extremely unusual architectural feature for Gothic Revival buildings that makes this cathedral a rare hybrid of Western Gothic and Eastern Orthodox design elements.

The exterior showcases a striking combination of white stone construction with decorative red stone elements, creating a dramatic color contrast that distinguishes it from traditional monochromatic Gothic cathedrals.

Above the main entrance stand statues of apostles, though debates continue among scholars and locals about whom they represent—some argue for St. Andrew the Apostle and Simon the Cananaean, while others claim they depict St. Mary and Joseph.

The interior features vibrant frescoes depicting scenes from the Old and New Testaments adorning the walls, with the four Evangelists painted beneath the cupola and the twelve Apostles positioned above the candlesticks.

An elaborate Orthodox iconostasis adorned with gilded icons and frescoes depicting scenes from the life of the Virgin Mary serves as the focal point of the sanctuary, representing the cathedral's transformation from Catholic to Orthodox worship.

The cathedral is constructed with special stones that exhibit remarkable color variations depending on weather conditions, adding an element of mystery and visual dynamism to the building's appearance.

High rib-vaulted ceilings following traditional Gothic spatial proportions create a sense of soaring verticality inside the single-nave basilica, enhanced by the pointed arches and elaborate stone carvings.
Twin bell towers stand watch on the eastern facade, their spires reaching skyward and serving as prominent landmarks visible throughout Batumi's city center.
The building represents the only Gothic church in Georgia, making it an architectural anomaly and a precious example of Western European ecclesiastical design in the Caucasus region.
tips: Visit in the morning between 8-10 AM for the most peaceful experience with fewer crowds and the opportunity to observe devout locals at prayer, or attend an evening service to hear the cathedral's renowned choir perform.

Dress modestly and respectfully as this is a functioning Orthodox place of worship—women must wear dresses or long skirts and cover their heads with a scarf, while men must wear long trousers; free shawls, scarves, and cloths are available at the entrance to meet dress code requirements.
Entry to the cathedral is completely free, though donations are welcomed and appreciated if you wish to light a candle or contribute to the church's maintenance and restoration efforts.

Photography inside the cathedral is prohibited out of respect for worshippers and the sacred space, but the stunning exterior offers excellent photo opportunities, especially during golden hour in late afternoon when the white and red stone facade glows beautifully.

Combine your visit with a walk through Batumi's Turkish quarter along Kutaisi Street, where the cathedral is located at number 25, to experience the city's multicultural heritage including Turkish shops, cafes, teahouses, and the nearby Orta-Jame Mosque built in 1866.
Visit during a service or choir performance for a truly special and immersive experience—the acoustics of the Gothic vaulted ceilings amplify the Orthodox chants and hymns magnificently.

Spend time examining the stained glass windows from different angles and at different times of day to fully appreciate how the changing light transforms the interior atmosphere and creates shifting patterns of colorful illumination.
Look for the small garden area outside the cathedral, though it may appear somewhat overgrown and neglected; it offers a quiet spot for reflection away from Batumi's bustling streets.

Ask permission before taking photos of people praying or participating in religious services, and be mindful that even small gestures can be seen as disrespectful given how deeply religious the local congregation is.

The cathedral is located in central Batumi within easy walking distance of other major attractions including the Old Town, Batumi Boulevard, and the Piazza, making it an ideal stop on a historic walking tour.

Be aware that the cathedral shows some wear and aging, with restoration work ongoing for the century-old frescoes, so temper expectations of pristine condition and view it as a living, working church rather than a museum piece.

Visit the modern Church of the Holy Spirit, consecrated in 2000, if you're interested in seeing where Batumi's Roman Catholic community now worships after the cathedral was transferred to the Orthodox Church.
vibe: The Holy Mother Virgin Nativity Cathedral emanates a profound sense of peaceful spirituality mixed with historical resilience. Stepping through its doors feels like entering a sanctuary where Gothic grandeur meets Orthodox devotion—the soaring rib-vaulted ceilings draw your eyes upward while the kaleidoscopic light filtering through the magnificent stained glass windows creates an almost ethereal, otherworldly atmosphere. The air carries the lingering scent of incense and burning candles, while the sound of whispered prayers and the occasional choir's haunting chants echo through the stone interior. Unlike the pristine, museum-like quality of some famous European cathedrals, this space feels authentically lived-in and actively used, with devout locals genuflecting before icons and elderly women in headscarves moving quietly through their prayers. The atmosphere oscillates between the contemplative silence of individual worship and the communal energy during services, when the Georgian Orthodox liturgy fills every corner of the building. Outside, the cathedral exists in fascinating juxtaposition with its surroundings—a Gothic Revival masterpiece standing on a street in the Turkish quarter, with minarets visible nearby and the sounds of multilingual conversation drifting from surrounding cafes and shops. The slightly weathered condition and modest green space outside, while not manicured or grandiose, contribute to an authentic, unpretentious character that makes the cathedral feel more approachable and genuine than intimidating or overly formal.
expectations: Visitors expect a massive, grand cathedral comparable in scale to famous European Gothic cathedrals like Notre-Dame or Cologne Cathedral, anticipating soaring heights and vast interior spaces.
Many assume the cathedral will be in pristine, well-maintained condition with perfectly manicured grounds and meticulously preserved interiors given its architectural significance.
Tourists often expect the building to be primarily a historical monument or museum-like attraction that happens to hold occasional services, similar to many famous European churches.
Visitors anticipate that a Gothic cathedral will follow pure Western European architectural conventions without any hybrid elements or Eastern Orthodox influences.
Many expect the cathedral to be isolated in its own plaza or surrounded by formal gardens, standing as the dominant architectural feature in its immediate area.
reality: The cathedral is actually quite intimate and modest in scale compared to major European Gothic cathedrals—visitors often describe it as smaller than expected, though perfectly sized for Batumi and charming in its proportions rather than overwhelming.

The building shows its age and the wear of over 120 years, with ongoing restoration work on frescoes, somewhat neglected green spaces outside with overgrown vegetation, and a patina that tells the story of its tumultuous history including decades as a Soviet laboratory.

This is first and foremost an active, functioning Orthodox church serving a deeply religious local congregation—services, prayers, and religious observances take clear precedence over tourism, and the spiritual atmosphere is palpable and authentic rather than performative.

The cathedral is a fascinating architectural hybrid featuring three domes (highly unusual for Gothic design) and Orthodox elements like an elaborate iconostasis with gilded icons, seamlessly blending Western Gothic Revival style with Eastern Orthodox traditions.

The cathedral sits directly on Kutaisi Street in Batumi's vibrant Turkish quarter, surrounded by Turkish shops, cafes, teahouses, and with the Orta-Jame Mosque visible nearby, creating a wonderfully multicultural urban context rather than formal isolation.
unique_facts: The cathedral was commissioned by the Zubalashvili brothers, legendary Georgian Catholic philanthropists whose archival records date back to the 1680s and who funded numerous public buildings including Tbilisi's Kote Marjanishvili State Drama Theatre and the Tbilisi State Conservatoire, as well as Georgia's first pediatric hospital.
Polish architect Aleksander Rogojski designed the cathedral, bringing authentic European Gothic Revival expertise to Georgia's Black Sea coast and creating the country's only true Gothic church.

During the Soviet era from the 1930s until 1989, this sacred space was bizarrely repurposed as a high-voltage laboratory, with religious artifacts removed and electrical equipment installed where worshippers once prayed.

The Zubalashvili brothers built the cathedral specifically in response to their mother's wish for a memorial to her soul, making this magnificent structure an extraordinarily elaborate and enduring act of filial devotion.

Construction took five years from 1898 to 1903, during a period when Batumi experienced an influx of foreign citizens including Catholics following Adjaria's annexation by the Russian Empire, creating demand for Catholic worship space.

The cathedral's stained glass windows are so exceptional that they are considered competitive with the finest examples of French Gothic architecture, an extraordinary claim for a church built on the edge of the Caucasus.

After the cathedral was transferred to the Georgian Orthodox Church in 1989, Batumi's Roman Catholic community had to establish a completely new church, the Church of the Holy Spirit, which was consecrated in 2000.

Levan, Jacob, and Petre Zubalashvili were awarded the title of Honorary Citizens of Tbilisi in 1913 in recognition of their philanthropy, while their brother Nikoloz had died in 1898 and was honored with a bust of green marble.

The cathedral's consecration by Catholicos-Patriarch Elijah II on May 16, 1989, came during Perestroika's religious revival, making it one of the first major religious properties restored to the Orthodox Church after decades of Soviet atheism.

The special stones used in the cathedral's construction exhibit remarkable chromatic properties, changing color depending on weather conditions and giving the building an almost mystical, changeable appearance.

The building represents a triple-naved basilica with a single nave featuring rib-vaulted ceilings, following traditional Gothic spatial proportions rarely seen in Georgian ecclesiastical architecture.

Many locals and even guidebooks have forgotten that the cathedral was originally built as a Roman Catholic church, with the Orthodox transformation so complete that its Catholic origins have become historical trivia rather than common knowledge.
surprises: The cathedral sits on the same street as the Orta-Jame Mosque in Batumi's Turkish quarter, where you'll hear the Muslim call to prayer echoing alongside Orthodox church bells, creating a fascinating soundtrack of religious pluralism.

Despite its Gothic architecture suggesting Western European influence, the interior feels thoroughly Georgian Orthodox with elaborate frescoes, ornate iconostasis, and the distinctive smell and atmosphere of Eastern Christian worship.

The congregation is remarkably devout and the religious observance deeply authentic—this isn't a tourist attraction that happens to hold services, but a genuine spiritual center where tourism is secondary to worship.

The debate among scholars and locals about which saints the entrance statues represent (St. Andrew and Simon the Cananaean versus St. Mary and Joseph) adds an element of mystery and ongoing discussion to the cathedral's iconography.

The green spaces outside are notably modest and somewhat overgrown rather than the manicured gardens you might expect around a cathedral, giving the site an unpretentious, neighborhood church feeling despite its architectural grandeur.

Free dress code items (shawls, scarves, cloths) are readily available at the entrance without judgment or hassle, making the cathedral welcoming to tourists unfamiliar with Orthodox customs rather than exclusionary.

The cathedral's history as a Soviet high-voltage laboratory seems almost impossible to imagine when you see the sacred space today, yet this bizarre chapter adds depth to the building's story of survival and transformation.
The stained glass windows create dramatically different interior atmospheres depending on the time of day and weather conditions, making each visit a potentially unique visual experience.

The cathedral serves as a social gathering point for elderly locals, particularly women, who treat it as a daily spiritual destination rather than just a Sunday church, giving the space a lived-in, community center quality.

Photography is strictly prohibited inside, which initially disappoints tourists but ultimately enhances the spiritual authenticity and encourages visitors to be fully present rather than documenting everything.

The multicultural neighborhood context—Turkish shops, cafes, and teahouses surrounding a Gothic Catholic-turned-Orthodox cathedral—creates a wonderfully complex cultural layering that challenges simple narratives about Georgian identity.

The ongoing restoration work on the century-old frescoes means you're witnessing the cathedral as a living, evolving historical artifact rather than a completed preservation project, adding a sense of continuity between past and present.
